Hopkins Hospital files $1.1 million suit against FCLC
By ALLEN SHORT
Hopkins Hospital has filed a
$1.1 million suit against the
Federal Cost of Living Council,
charging that CLC regulations
governing financial operations at
health institutions are
"arbitrary" and "capricious".
Filed in Federal District Court
here August 23, but disclosed
only last week, the suit seeks
punitive damages from the
council in the approximate
amount the hospital lost on
operations during the fiscal year
that ended June 30.
According to hospital treasurer
W. Thomas Barnes, the suit
contends that deficits in
operating costs should be
absorbed by paying patients in
the form of higher room and
medical service rates.
"The effect of these
regulations is to force institutions
which have been operating at a
loss to continue to do so,"
Barnes said.
Since the hospital's most
recent hike in room and medical
services fees in June, 1972, prices
of hospital supplies have
increased by over eight percent,
he explained.

Price Commission's denial of the
increase request, Hopkins filed a
number of administrative appeals
to federal officials—all of which
were denied.
"We've tried everything we can
but to no avail. We feel the issue
is serious enough to pursue it to
this extent," Barnes commented
Hopkins is the first Maryland
hospital to file such a suit, but
hospital officials said they
"wouldn't be surprised "if other
area medical facilities sooned
filed similar actions."
Barnes predicted that average
increases in hospital charges, if

The treasurer was apparently
referring to the East Baltimore
Medical Plan, Hopkins' partially
subsidized inner city health care
delivery program.
Barnes said the hospital has
never broken even on operating
expenditures since it opened its
doors in the 1880's. "But that
doesn't mean that we should
continue to operate at a loss," he
said.
Previous operating deficits,
averaging - $1 million annually
during the last five years, have
been covered by endowment
income, according to Barnes.

W. Thomas Barnes
Under current CLC
regulations, medical institutions
are prohibibited from exceeding
the average level of profits during
the best two years of the last
five. Barnes said Hopkins' most
successful year in hospital
operation, FY 1972, recorded a
$439,000 loss.
The suit is the most recent of
several steps Hopkins has taken
in the last year to gain
government approval for
increased charges. Last

MSE address today
Dr. Frank Manuel, Kenan
Professor of History at New York
University, will deliver the third
address of the Milton S.
Eisenhower Symposium on
"Living with Change" today at 4
p.m. in Shriver Hall.
Manuel will be the first of
three speakers to address the
Symposium this week.
Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Dr. Barry
Commoner, Director of the
Center for the Biology of Natural
Systems at Washington
University, will speak on the
"Change in Man's Response to
his Environment".
The following day, October
11, at 4 p.m., Dr. Harvey Cox,
Victor Thomas Professor of
Divinity at the Harvard Divinity
School, will deliver the
Symposium's fifth address, "The
Seduction af the Spirit". Cox,as
well as Commoner, will speak in
Shriver Hall.
Manuel's topic of discussion
will be the "Impact of Change in
the 20th Century". According to
Symposium co-chairman David
Yaffe, Manuel is to talk on "how
things changed before the 20th
Century and then discuss how
later technological advancements
have changed man's relations in
relation to man."
. Manuel, who spent the last
semester at Oxford University,
has a background in government
as well as in academics and is the
author of several books.

Move to kill intersession tabled
A proposal to move the start
of spring semester to the middle
of January and eliminate the
intersession was tabled by the
faculty General Assembly at its
Fall meeting Friday afternoon.
The proposal, made by Dr.
Joseph Sampson, Mathematics,
had been tabled by the Assembly
at its May meeting but was taken
up again Friday. Sampson said he
made the proposal for two
reasons. "I object to the
minimester. It's been slipped over
on us," he asserted.
"I don't think much of
minimester courses in general,
anyway," he stated and he
pointed out that minimester puts
pressure on departmenis to offer
courses during the three-week
period, even though
departmental participation was
voluntary when the program was
established.
Only five faculty nrnbeis voted
against the tabling of Sampson's

motion, which was amended to
provide for establishment of a
committee to study calendar
revisions.
If the Sampson motion had
passed and gone into effect, the
academic year would have ended
in early May, allowing for a
four-month summer vacation.
Although his motion was not
voted on, Sampson pledged that
he would not let the minimester
issue die, although he would not
say when he would bring it up
again.
In other business, President
Muller promised the faculty that
Hopkins would do all it could to
keep the current steep inflation
from eroding professors' pay and
also committed himself to
preventing a further decline in
numbers of graduate students .
enrolled here. Currently,
approximately 970 grads are
enrolled, compared to 1060 at
this time last year. He said the

University could handle as many
as 1500.
"The low number of graduate
students here is a waste of
Hopkins' resources," Muller said.
"The number is not due to a lack
of qualified students, but to a
'lack of support for them," he
stated. He also said Hopkins
lacked sufficient funds for
undergraduate aid.
The bulk of the money to
support increased graduate
enrollment, will come from
outside sources, Muller indicated,
and he said that Hopkins is now
talking to foundations capable of
providing financial assistance.
As much as $I million more in
state aid to Hopkins will be
provided next year if the
legislature approves a committee
report recommending an
$800,000 to $I million increase
in aid to Hopkins. Last year,
Maryland granted the University
$900,000 for general use.

Hopkins Club maintains glowing reputation
By CAROL TRZCINSKI
Unobstrusively tucked away in
a wooded section on the west
side of campus, the Johns
Hopkins Club, housed in a 1936
two-floor Georgian structure
quietly maintains an
international reputation as one of
the best university clubs in the
world.
The' small, intimate club,
known by many as "The Faculty
Club", serves a substantially
larger clientele than the present
teaching staff at Hopkins. The
4200 members,including faculty,
alumni, and other subscribers
from all over the world, flock to
the Club, established in 1923.
The Hopkins Club, a separate
corporation from the University,
is manned by 45 management
and staff employees, including
veteran waitresses, hostesses, and
a neophyte manager of only two
year's experience, Dick
Cartwright.
According to some from
around the country, we are one

of the two or three best
university clubs in the country,"
boasts Cartwright upon
introducing a visitor to the
venerable establishment.
Cartwright, who has been in
the food-serving business for
fifteen years, and at the Hopkins'
club since May 1971, runs his
business on a simple

The Johns Hopkins Club
sophisticated in the dining room,
but in the kitchen, all hell breaks
loose."
Since taking over the reins of
manager, Cartwright has
instituted changes in the club,
especially in its membership" and
patronage policy.

the opening of the club for use

47% offrosh turn out for primary elections
By ALAN HIRSCH
Members of the freshman class'
elected four Honor Commission
representatives and selected
candidates for run-off election of
class officers and Student
Council Representatives in last
week's preliminary Freshmen
elections.
The run-off election will be
conducted this Wednesday,
Thursday, and Friday in the
Dormitory Dining Halls at dinner
time. Two hundred and eighty

four ballots were cast in last
week's elections, representing 47
percent of this year's 594
freshmen.
Elected to serve as Freshmen
rep res'entatives on the honor
commission were Kathy
Belmonte, Susan Eyrich,
Christopher Howard, and Joan
McDermott. Howard was the.top
vote-getter with 146 votes.
Barbara Black will serve as
Freshmen Class treasurer. She ran
unopposed and was

automatically declared the
winner.
As a result of the preliminary
election, John Piccone and Mark
Spatola vie for the office of Class
president this week. Carlos Mock
and Paul Shapiro seek election as
Vice-President. Charles
Henderson and Brenda Bunson
compete for the position of
Secretary.
Five of the original seven
candidates for Student Council
Representative survived the

Centennial committee presses on
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
The Hopkin's Centennial
Committee has hired Dr. Robert
Sharkey to write a "brief,
readable and useful Hopkins
history" and Dr. Hugo Weisgall
to compose a "short choral ode
for the centennial."
Sharkey, a member of the
George Washington University
faculty, commenced his work in
June 1973, and completed the
research and principle writing
this summer, with the finishing
touches due to be added by next
summer. The book should be
available at the Centennial's start
in September 1975. Sharkey, a
former Hopkins faculty member,
is the author of "Johns Hopkins,
Portrait of a University".
Sharkey is the second historian
hired by the committee to
attempt to write a history of
Hopkins. The first, hired during
the Lincoln Gordon
administration, began his work in
July -1970 but resigned six
months later.
Dr. Ferdinand Hamburger,
Director of Central Planning for
the 1 975-76 Johns Hopkins
Centennial, stated that several
more programs for the centennial
were added during the summer.
During the opening week of
classes in the fall 1975 term the
opening ceremony for the
Centennial Celebration will
commence. This would be held
on September 10, 1975 on the
Keyser Quadrangle of the
Homewood Campus. Among the
participants and activities
scheduled for the program that
day include an opening address
by the Governor of Maryland and

Dr. Ferdinand Hamburger
the Mayor of Baltimore, the
Installation of the Hopkins
Hundreds Professors by President
Muller, a major address by the
President of Harvard or a
Historian, as well as a musical
interlude by the Peabody group.
The Centennial committee has
purchased, through the donation
of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Levi,
along with a hopeful matching
grant from the National
Endowment for the Arts, a
centennial sculpture. Sculpted by
David Lee Brown, the object "is
a contemporary piece of art
fabricated from square tubes of
mirror-polished stainless steel...It
will be located on the quadrangle
side of the MSE Library atop a
six foot pedestal astride the
terrace wall north of the Library
entrance," according to the
centennial latest report. The
sculpture would be dedicated

McManus decries British presence in Ireland
Calling the violence in Ireland
"a continuation of an age-old
problem of the. Irish fight for
independence from a conquering
power," Father Sean McManus
delivered a strong address on
"The Conflict in Northern
Ireland - Politics of Religion" to
last weekend's Sunday
Experience audience.
McManus expressed his
resentment of the British
presence in Northern Ireland by
labeling the situation "a
deliberately declared supremacy
of one people over another."
Drawing on various historical
incidents to illustrate his point,
McManus attempted to reveal in
his talk the extent to which
British policy has helped bring

about the violent discontent that
is present in his native
countryland.
The speaker cited a 1918
incident as being the primary
instigation for the continual
fighting that has occurred over
much of this century between
the two countries. At that time.
officials of the British
government in England nullified
the results of an election in
which 83.5 percent of Ireland
voted in favor of independence
from the mother country.
Defending further his feeling
that the situation in N. Ireland is
overwhelmingly political in
nature, McManus pointed out
that the unemployment rate in
nationalist and anti-British sects

Academicians, like most other people, can be very
petty at times, and the proposal made at last week's faculty General Assembly meeting to eliminate minimestcr by
moving the start of the spring term from late January to
the middle of the month appears to be just one more example of that tendency. According to Dr. Joseph Sampson
the author of the proposal, the reason behind his motion to change the calendar was that minimester had been
"slipped over on us." More to the point, Dr. Sampson,
stated after the meeting, "I don't think much of minimester courses anyway."
While it may be true that very little mathematics can
be taught in a three-week period, it seems unfair that one
department should seek to solve its problems with minimester by doing away with the program entirely.
There are other areas, both academic and nonacademic, in which worthwhile three-week programs can
be designed, and the present three-week break is also ideal
for students who seek to pursue independent study programs they cannot fit into a regular term's schedule.
Further, disguising the proposal to kill the rpinimester
program, in the form of a minor calendar change is an indefensible kind of sneaky politics. While no one present at
the faculty meeting Friday was fooled for very long concerning the real intention of the proposal to change the
calendar, the effort to obscure the true. nature of the issue implies a real contempt for the intelligence , and the
integrity, of the faculty here. No matter what their opinions of the minimester may be, the faculty showed by its
action Friday that it will not let itself be fooled on a major educational issue. Hopefully the next time a disgruntled faculty member wants to change a policy, he will go
about it in a more open way.

his final publication.
For if the committee hadn't included "brief" in its directive to the historian, certainly one of the most interesting and illustrative of his Homewood Tales would consist
of a synopsis of the History of the Student Union. It
seems, from reading the yellowed parchment of long-gone
News-Letter issues, that the saga began when union architect Donald Sickler submitted his plans for the structure
two weeks late, in September 1972. Though we're certain
he didn't realize at the time the significance of his tardy
action, Sickler must be given credit for founding one of
the most pervasive_ and treasured of all Hopkins' traditions
--delaying the Union.
In fact, that tradition has seen Hopkins' administrators, contractors, and construction "crews, (not to mention
the fellows at the Pilkington Glassworks), turn what
Sickler estimated to be a $1.3 million, nine-month job
into a $1.8 million headache which University officials
now concede will take fourteen months to complete, God
willing.
But because we sympathize with Dr. Weisgull in his
assigned task of sifting the historically significant events
from the myriads of everyday experiences logged in the
Hopkins archives, and especially because the Union is not
yet completed, we will certainly understand why, if in his
final. history, Dr. Weisgull includes only the famous Macke
machine invasion in his chapter on Student Union, and
not the whole, uncompleted story.

To the Editor:
The Goucher Gallop is an annual
race run on a Saturday afternoon
in the Fall, under the auspices of
the BIA. For some
incomprehensible reason, the date
chosen this year, October 6, was
also the date of Yom Icippur, a
Jewish High Holy Day. Upon
learning of their oversight, the
Executive Board of the Student
Council immediately expressed its
displeasure to Colonel Serena, the

BIA advisor, who, in turn,
informed the BIA. As the elected
voice of the Student Body, we had
hoped that they 'might comply
with Our request for
postponement.
The Gallop was run on
Saturday.
We would now like to apologize
to. those students who were
offended by the insensitivity of the
BIA.
The Executive Board of the SC

Future Features: The Role of Art as Hope
For just a journalistic instant, an issue, I
would like to use the feature page to
describe the changes it will undergo in
future issues. The important matter is the
connection between the people and the
way they choose to express themselves. In
this case with words. People whose
profession contains the usage of words are
not necessarily more expressive, artistic or
sensitive. In fact, an excessive exposure to
college type journalism might indeed
Philistinize an otherwise creative
individual.
There was a time when most American
writers of the non-elite saw journalism as a
sort of apprentice work, part of the rites
de passage associated with learning one's
crafts, as a necessary step toward later
serious writing. Hemingway and %Mace
Stevens are only two writers who spent

in places
where men have died in knife-fights
where the sun settles before the dust
where it sometimes rains at night
where you also died, perhaps
and the words are almost dreams
forgetting the dry riverbeds
from which they rise
and the words are filled
with their own names
with days
with their useless, forgotten
and the words arrange themselves
somehow

beside a river,
beside an ocean
that they are lost in cities
that they are the same words, once spoken
in love, or almost love,
as they will be spoken again,
beside naked girls at night

that they startle us with memories...
no,
it doesn't much matter,
no, not tonight

but they have already travelled too far
and there are gaps

reasons. They can express fact or fiction,
intellectual concepts or emotional
outbursts. They can symbolize life or
death. And words can mean nothing at all.
As expressors of facts and intellectualism
they are fine if they are understood by all
those concerned. As expressions of
emotion between two or more loving
people they run a poor second to any
other forms of communication they can
find. As artistic expressions with artistic
intent they hold no pretentions and are
beyond any value criticism. There is only
one usage of words then that can always
have significance for any human being as a
human being and that is those used for
creative expression, which are appreciated
or understood by other people. This is a
universal language in that it touches the
harpstrings of humanity - so to speak.
revealed by art.
My point then is that as far as a piece of
paper with all types of words on it goes,
the following type aren't printed on it
very often. Not that they shouldn't mind
you but that these days people are blinded
from art by society's many chains and are
thus made afraid of it. And words can
mean nothing at all.
Here is a representation of poetry from
one of the News-Letter's past editors:

there are nights which are nearly dark,
when words rise up like weightless stones
to line the almost forgotten
violent streets of air

society, but I'm convinced that some sort

of non-substantive beauty must at least be
essayed, if anyone at all is to regain the
sanity necessary to cope adequately with a
sort of life where we often forget that all
this cement is actually put over the bare
earth.
What
about people who read your poetry'?
"It's difficult to find people who are
willing to approach poetry with any sort
of proper attitude. One of the difficulties
that writers feel and I think that this is
important, is that readers bring their own
prejudices to the work, and seldom are
willing to. acknowledge that anything
could move them. This often controls the
reading of any attempted work of art, and
precludes any real consideration of what
the artist is trying to do."
Would you please criticize your work?

are getting underway,
and we are drunk already
too drunk to stop our dancing
too drunk to stop our singing
and we talk about the women we have loved
how one day they turned to girls
how they walked away or vanished,
mirth on their foreheads,
how they simply walked away
and we talk about how men decline
as women grow,
how upset we are with weddings,
how those beautiful girls are just too good
for those bastards they want to marry

and we know we are too drunk
to make sense of that
river which never flows uphill,
which always passes beyond us,
beyond our senses...
but it always ends in drunken laughter...
and no,
it doesn't much matter,
no, not tonight
that our words are wrong
that they are out of order
that they take up too much space in the mind
that they die before they are spoken
that they are nothing beside a sunrise,

silence grows between the sounds,
water
seeping through the cracks of thought,
silent,
filled with dusty afternoons,
paths lined by stones,
with time,
memories,
with the night,
with all the women who ever were,
with all the women that were not.

It's just not the Dow Jones Industrial
Average, the Symposium, "I love you", or
the ReNewed WAR in the middle east.
Some people call it poetry, words of an
artist put together not for meaning but to
connect entire experiences of humanity.
In any case, this one page of poetry is
more representative of B.H. Cohen than
three\ years of other affiliations with the
J.H.U. More than any newspaper story on
our political action with Goucher, or other
informative material that made such a
heavy impression on you and how you
perceive your relationship with reality.
The following comments were taken
from an interview with the author.
How do you feel about the role of art in
mankind?
"I'm not really convinced that there's
any reason per se for my writing in this

poetry is an art and not a craft, 1 still have
a long way to go. It's not a question of my
writing at some point in the future, better
than anyone else, but of writing
effectively, without mistakes, without
being as self-conscious of my gestu rings as
I now am,and of developing something, in
some way, significant."
The reason I chose this particular
author to interview is that he represents,
generally, my opinions of the role and
importance of art in our society. I feel
that art is the hope of mankind and that it
is something that is vastly neglected at
Hopkins, which should not be neglected,
ever. In the future, the feature page will
try to bring to its Hopkins audience a
sounder and broader view of the ways in
which men can express themselves more
naturally, and more about personal
relationships between people and the way
they experience their lives. This does not
mean that this will be the arts section of
the newspaper, but I hope it will be the
page where people express what is
important to them. The page will include
reviews of various books, movies, plays,
etc. There, will also be articles by various
people who have something they wish to
say that pertains to the format of the
page. Anyone who wishes is encouraged to
send in written or drawn material for
consideration in the page. Written material
should be from three to six double-spaced
typewritten pages. The address is:

Offense shines as Hopkins nabs first grid win
Two Harry Stringer
touchdown runs and a 231 total
offense performance by
quarterback Jack Thomas led the
Blue Jays to a 34-13 victory over
the hapless Ursinus Bears
Saturday in the first Hopkins win
of the 1973 football season.
Co-captain Thomas connected
on ten of his fifteen passes and
gained 94 yards on the ground,
including a ten yard third period
scamper into the endzone and a
47 yard display of broken field
elusiveness that set up the first
score of the afternoon.
"We improved in execution
tremendously," asserted Coach
Dennis Cox, attributing the

triumph to the team effort.
"The line is working much
better each week," he continued.
"The flip-flop idea is paying off,
for they are developing much
faster." The success of the
offesnive line is apparenrin the
productive rushing game and the
fact that Thomas had time to get
off accurate passes. This week
none of his throws were
purloined.
Defensively, the Bears were
hampered by the loss of All-MAC
middle guard Rick Abernethy,
who broke his ankle last week.
However, Ursinus was throttled
by the Blue Jay defenders all
afternoon and could not mount a
threat until the fourth quarter

after their fate had been sealed.
The Hopkins secondary was
particularly effective, blanketing
Bear receivers and picking off
ifive passes during the contest.
Freshman Brian Coulter's first
interception as a Blue Jay set up
the Thomas touchdown run
which concluded the Hopkins
scoring.
Brian's brother Jack opened
the scoring by pulling in an eight
yard Thomas pass in the waning
moments of the first quarter.
After Ursinus missed a field goal
attempt, Thomas hit Bill Nolan
for a 58 yard gain, with Stringer
tallying three plays later to give
the Blue Jays a 14-0 advantage.
After an exchange of

turnovers, freshman Mike
Rhodey cairn into his own with a
pair of strong runs and a five
yard score. "This awakening
should do a world of good for his
confidence," claimed Coach Cox
in regard to the converted
quarterback. Rhodey picked up
57 yards in six carries.
Thomas himself met with
success in the running
department. The F & M game
films showed that he had several
chances to pick up good yardage
on his roll outs, so the senior
signal caller purposefully
concentrated on the outside run
opportunities against Ursinus.
Thomas' gallops picked up
several key first downs for the

Good weather gives
Goucher Gallop go
In the most popular Goucher
Gallop of recent years, Kerry
Spaven's first place finish led
Willard to the dormitory title
while TEP prevailed over the
fraternity entries.
More than twice as many
runners than usual participated
this year, with fifty-eight
successfully completing the mile
and a half course. B1A President
Neil Hazard attributed the large
turnout to the brilliant weather
and the later noon start.
Spaven ran the course in 6:45
to beat out TEP's Doug
Southard for individual honors.
Mark Lewis, also of Willard,
placed third to give his house a

commanding advantage. Leo
Kusuda rounded out the Willard
win as the 20th man to complete
the course.
Griffin took second and
Sylvester placed third in the
dormitory competition.
TEP earned the lowest score of
all teams with Rick Jennings
finishing third and Ed Casey
copping the tenth spot for a team
total of 20. PI Kappa Alpha was
second with Sigma Nu and DU
rounding out the top fraternities.
The B1A bike race will be run
Saturday at 11 a.m. Entrants
must register with Chris Brescia
by Thursday at Box 69 or
243-9209.

By ALLEN SHORT
Hopkins Hospital has filed a
$1.1 million suit against the
Federal Cost of Living Council,
charging that CLC regulations
governing financial operations at
health institutions are
"arbitrary" and "capricious".
Filed in Federal District Court
here August 23, but disclosed
only last week, the suit seeks
punitive damages from the
council in the approximate
amount the hospital lost on
operations during the fiscal year
that ended June 30.
According to hospital treasurer
W. Thomas Barnes, the suit
contends that deficits in
operating costs should be
absorbed by paying patients in
the form of higher room and
medical service rates.
"The effect of these
regulations is to force institutions
which have been operating at a
loss to continue to do so,"
Barnes said.
Since the hospital's most
recent hike in room and medical
services fees in June, 1972, prices
of hospital supplies have
increased by over eight percent,
he explained.

Move to kill intersession tabled
A proposal to move the start
of spring semester to the middle
of January and eliminate the
intersession was tabled by the
faculty General Assembly at its
Fall meeting Friday afternoon.
The proposal, made by Dr.
Joseph Sampson, Mathematics,
had been tabled by the Assembly
at its May meeting but was taken
up again Friday. Sampson said he
made the proposal for two
reasons. "I object to the
minimester. It's been slipped over
on us," he asserted.
"I don't think much of
minimester courses in general,
anyway," he stated and he
pointed out that minimester puts
pressure on departmenis to offer
courses during the three-week
period, even though
departmental participation was
voluntary when the program was
established.
Only five faculty nrnbeis voted
against the tabling of Sampson's

motion, which was amended to
provide for establishment of a
committee to study calendar
revisions.
If the Sampson motion had
passed and gone into effect, the
academic year would have ended
in early May, allowing for a
four-month summer vacation.
Although his motion was not
voted on, Sampson pledged that
he would not let the minimester
issue die, although he would not
say when he would bring it up
again.
In other business, President
Muller promised the faculty that
Hopkins would do all it could to
keep the current steep inflation
from eroding professors' pay and
also committed himself to
preventing a further decline in
numbers of graduate students .
enrolled here. Currently,
approximately 970 grads are
enrolled, compared to 1060 at
this time last year. He said the

University could handle as many
as 1500.
"The low number of graduate
students here is a waste of
Hopkins' resources," Muller said.
"The number is not due to a lack
of qualified students, but to a
'lack of support for them," he
stated. He also said Hopkins
lacked sufficient funds for
undergraduate aid.
The bulk of the money to
support increased graduate
enrollment, will come from
outside sources, Muller indicated,
and he said that Hopkins is now
talking to foundations capable of
providing financial assistance.
As much as $I million more in
state aid to Hopkins will be
provided next year if the
legislature approves a committee
report recommending an
$800,000 to $I million increase
in aid to Hopkins. Last year,
Maryland granted the University
$900,000 for general use.

Hopkins Club maintains glowing reputation
By CAROL TRZCINSKI
Unobstrusively tucked away in
a wooded section on the west
side of campus, the Johns
Hopkins Club, housed in a 1936
two-floor Georgian structure
quietly maintains an
international reputation as one of
the best university clubs in the
world.
The' small, intimate club,
known by many as "The Faculty
Club", serves a substantially
larger clientele than the present
teaching staff at Hopkins. The
4200 members,including faculty,
alumni, and other subscribers
from all over the world, flock to
the Club, established in 1923.
The Hopkins Club, a separate
corporation from the University,

year's experience, Dick
Cartwright.

47% offrosh turn out for primary elections
By ALAN HIRSCH
Members of the freshman class'
elected four Honor Commission
representatives and selected
candidates for run-off election of
class officers and Student
Council Representatives in last
week's preliminary Freshmen
elections.
The run-off election will be
conducted this Wednesday,
Thursday, and Friday in the
Dormitory Dining Halls at dinner
time. Two hundred and eighty

four ballots were cast in last
week's elections, representing 47
percent of this year's 594
freshmen.
Elected to serve as Freshmen
rep res'entatives on the honor
commission were Kathy
Belmonte, Susan Eyrich,
Christopher Howard, and Joan
McDermott. Howard was the.top
vote-getter with 146 votes.
Barbara Black will serve as
Freshmen Class treasurer. She ran
unopposed and was

automatically declared the
winner.
As a result of the preliminary
election, John Piccone and Mark
Spatola vie for the office of Class
president this week. Carlos Mock
and Paul Shapiro seek election as
Vice-President. Charles
Henderson and Brenda Bunson
compete for the position of
Secretary.
Five of the original seven
candidates for Student Council
Representative survived the

Centennial committee presses on
By JAY S. GOODGOLD
The Hopkin's Centennial
Committee has hired Dr. Robert
Sharkey to write a "brief,
readable and useful Hopkins
history" and Dr. Hugo Weisgall
to compose a "short choral ode
for the centennial."
Sharkey, a member of the
George Washington University
faculty, commenced his work in
June 1973, and completed the
research and principle writing
this summer, with the finishing
touches due to be added by next
summer. The book should be
available at the Centennial's start
in September 1975. Sharkey, a
former Hopkins faculty member,
is the author of "Johns Hopkins,
Portrait of a University".
Sharkey is the second historian
hired by the committee to
attempt to write a history of
Hopkins. The first, hired during
the Lincoln Gordon
administration, began his work in
July -1970 but resigned six
months later.
Dr. Ferdinand Hamburger,
Director of Central Planning for
the 1 975-76 Johns Hopkins
Centennial, stated that several
more programs for the centennial
were added during the summer.
During the opening week of
classes in the fall 1975 term the
opening ceremony for the
Centennial Celebration will
commence. This would be held
on September 10, 1975 on the
Keyser Quadrangle of the
Homewood Campus. Among the
participants and activities
scheduled for the program that
day include an opening address
by the Governor of Maryland and

Dr. Ferdinand Hamburger
the Mayor of Baltimore, the
Installation of the Hopkins
Hundreds Professors by President
Muller, a major address by the
President of Harvard or a
Historian, as well as a musical
interlude by the Peabody group.
The Centennial committee has
purchased, through the donation
of Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Levi,
along with a hopeful matching
grant from the National
Endowment for the Arts, a
centennial sculpture. Sculpted by
David Lee Brown, the object "is
a contemporary piece of art
fabricated from square tubes of
mirror-polished stainless steel...It
will be located on the quadrangle
side of the MSE Library atop a
six foot pedestal astride the
terrace wall north of the Library
entrance," according to the
centennial latest report. The
sculpture would be dedicated

preliminary election and will vie
for the three Freshmen Council
Representative slots. The five
candidates are Nancy Brighton,
Tim Daniles, Eugene Mauro,
John Perrotta, and Lola
Stawowy.
In the preliminary elections
for SC representatives, top
vote-getter John Perrotta tallied
136 votes. Tim Daniles' total of
67, the lowest of the five run-off
candidates, was only two greater
than those of now eliminated

Thomas Pressley, who both

Presidential candidate
Spatola's total of 71 was four
better than that of his adversary,
Piccone. Shapiro bettered his
run-off opponent Mock in V.P.
Preliminaries by 20 votes, 89-69.
Class Secretary candidate
Henderson obtained a four vote
edge over Bunson in last week's
initial balloting, 78-74.
"It's as good a Freshman
'election turnout as we can get,'-'
said SC President Andy Savitz of
last week's voter-turnout.
"However," Savitz continued, "it
isn't a satisfactory turnout for
me or the Student Council."
Savitz explained that the 47
percent turnout is not on par
with last year's school wide
election turnout of 65 percent.

McManus decries British presence in Ireland
Calling the violence in Ireland
"a continuation of an age-old
problem of the. Irish fight for
independence from a conquering
power," Father Sean McManus
delivered a strong address on
"The Conflict in Northern
Ireland - Politics of Religion" to
last weekend's Sunday
Experience audience.
McManus expressed his
resentment of the British
presence in Northern Ireland by
labeling the situation "a
deliberately declared supremacy
of one people over another."
Drawing on various historical
incidents to illustrate his point,
McManus attempted to reveal in
his talk the extent to which
British policy has helped bring

about the violent discontent that
is present in his native
countryland.
The speaker cited a 1918
incident as being the primary
instigation for the continual
fighting that has occurred over
much of this century between
the two countries. At that time.
officials of the British
government in England nullified
the results of an election in
which 83.5 percent of Ireland
voted in favor of independence
from the mother country.
Defending further his feeling
that the situation in N. Ireland is
overwhelmingly political in
nature, McManus pointed out
that the unemployment rate in

Academicians, like most other people, can be very
petty at times, and the proposal made at last week's faculty General Assembly meeting to eliminate minimestcr by
moving the start of the spring term from late January to
the middle of the month appears to be just one more example of that tendency. According to Dr. Joseph Sampson
the author of the proposal, the reason behind his motion to change the calendar was that minimester had been
"slipped over on us." More to the point, Dr. Sampson,
stated after the meeting, "I don't think much of minimester courses anyway."
While it may be true that very little mathematics can
be taught in a three-week period, it seems unfair that one
department should seek to solve its problems with minimester by doing away with the program entirely.
There are other areas, both academic and nonacademic, in which worthwhile three-week programs can
be designed, and the present three-week break is also ideal
for students who seek to pursue independent study programs they cannot fit into a regular term's schedule.
Further, disguising the proposal to kill the rpinimester
program, in the form of a minor calendar change is an indefensible kind of sneaky politics. While no one present at
the faculty meeting Friday was fooled for very long concerning the real intention of the proposal to change the
calendar, the effort to obscure the true. nature of the issue implies a real contempt for the intelligence , and the
integrity, of the faculty here. No matter what their opinions of the minimester may be, the faculty showed by its
action Friday that it will not let itself be fooled on a major educational issue. Hopefully the next time a disgruntled faculty member wants to change a policy, he will go
about it in a more open way.

his final publication.
For if the committee hadn't included "brief" in its directive to the historian, certainly one of the most interesting and illustrative of his Homewood Tales would consist
of a synopsis of the History of the Student Union. It
seems, from reading the yellowed parchment of long-gone
News-Letter issues, that the saga began when union architect Donald Sickler submitted his plans for the structure
two weeks late, in September 1972. Though we're certain
he didn't realize at the time the significance of his tardy
action, Sickler must be given credit for founding one of
the most pervasive_ and treasured of all Hopkins' traditions
--delaying the Union.
In fact, that tradition has seen Hopkins' administrators, contractors, and construction "crews, (not to mention
the fellows at the Pilkington Glassworks), turn what
Sickler estimated to be a $1.3 million, nine-month job
into a $1.8 million headache which University officials
now concede will take fourteen months to complete, God
willing.
But because we sympathize with Dr. Weisgull in his
assigned task of sifting the historically significant events
from the myriads of everyday experiences logged in the
Hopkins archives, and especially because the Union is not
yet completed, we will certainly understand why, if in his
final. history, Dr. Weisgull includes only the famous Macke
machine invasion in his chapter on Student Union, and
not the whole, uncompleted story.

To the Editor:
The Goucher Gallop is an annual
race run on a Saturday afternoon
in the Fall, under the auspices of
the BIA. For some
incomprehensible reason, the date
chosen this year, October 6, was
also the date of Yom Icippur, a
Jewish High Holy Day. Upon
learning of their oversight, the
Executive Board of the Student
Council immediately expressed its
displeasure to Colonel Serena, the

BIA advisor, who, in turn,
informed the BIA. As the elected
voice of the Student Body, we had
hoped that they 'might comply
with Our request for
postponement.
The Gallop was run on
Saturday.
We would now like to apologize
to. those students who were
offended by the insensitivity of the
BIA.
The Executive Board of the SC

Future Features: The Role of Art as Hope
For just a journalistic instant, an issue, I
would like to use the feature page to
describe the changes it will undergo in
future issues. The important matter is the
connection between the people and the
way they choose to express themselves. In
this case with words. People whose
profession contains the usage of words are
not necessarily more expressive, artistic or
sensitive. In fact, an excessive exposure to
college type journalism might indeed
Philistinize an otherwise creative
individual.
There was a time when most American
writers of the non-elite saw journalism as a
sort of apprentice work, part of the rites
de passage associated with learning one's
crafts, as a necessary step toward later
serious writing. Hemingway and %Mace
Stevens are only two writers who spent

in places
where men have died in knife-fights
where the sun settles before the dust
where it sometimes rains at night
where you also died, perhaps
and the words are almost dreams
forgetting the dry riverbeds
from which they rise
and the words are filled
with their own names
with days
with their useless, forgotten
and the words arrange themselves
somehow

beside a river,
beside an ocean
that they are lost in cities
that they are the same words, once spoken
in love, or almost love,
as they will be spoken again,
beside naked girls at night

that they startle us with memories...
no,
it doesn't much matter,
no, not tonight

but they have already travelled too far
and there are gaps

reasons. They can express fact or fiction,
intellectual concepts or emotional
outbursts. They can symbolize life or
death. And words can mean nothing at all.
As expressors of facts and intellectualism
they are fine if they are understood by all
those concerned. As expressions of
emotion between two or more loving
people they run a poor second to any
other forms of communication they can
find. As artistic expressions with artistic
intent they hold no pretentions and are
beyond any value criticism. There is only
one usage of words then that can always
have significance for any human being as a
human being and that is those used for
creative expression, which are appreciated
or understood by other people. This is a
universal language in that it touches the
harpstrings of humanity - so to speak.
revealed by art.
My point then is that as far as a piece of
paper with all types of words on it goes,
the following type aren't printed on it
very often. Not that they shouldn't mind
you but that these days people are blinded
from art by society's many chains and are
thus made afraid of it. And words can
mean nothing at all.
Here is a representation of poetry from
one of the News-Letter's past editors:

there are nights which are nearly dark,
when words rise up like weightless stones
to line the almost forgotten
violent streets of air

society, but I'm convinced that some sort

of non-substantive beauty must at least be
essayed, if anyone at all is to regain the
sanity necessary to cope adequately with a
sort of life where we often forget that all
this cement is actually put over the bare
earth.
What
about people who read your poetry'?
"It's difficult to find people who are
willing to approach poetry with any sort
of proper attitude. One of the difficulties
that writers feel and I think that this is
important, is that readers bring their own
prejudices to the work, and seldom are
willing to. acknowledge that anything
could move them. This often controls the
reading of any attempted work of art, and
precludes any real consideration of what
the artist is trying to do."
Would you please criticize your work?
"I'm not sure that what I'm writing

are getting underway,
and we are drunk already
too drunk to stop our dancing
too drunk to stop our singing
and we talk about the women we have loved
how one day they turned to girls
how they walked away or vanished,
mirth on their foreheads,
how they simply walked away
and we talk about how men decline
as women grow,
how upset we are with weddings,
how those beautiful girls are just too good
for those bastards they want to marry

and we know we are too drunk
to make sense of that
river which never flows uphill,
which always passes beyond us,
beyond our senses...
but it always ends in drunken laughter...
and no,
it doesn't much matter,
no, not tonight
that our words are wrong
that they are out of order
that they take up too much space in the mind
that they die before they are spoken
that they are nothing beside a sunrise,

silence grows between the sounds,
water
seeping through the cracks of thought,
silent,
filled with dusty afternoons,
paths lined by stones,
with time,
memories,
with the night,
with all the women who ever were,
with all the women that were not.

It's just not the Dow Jones Industrial
Average, the Symposium, "I love you", or
the ReNewed WAR in the middle east.
Some people call it poetry, words of an
artist put together not for meaning but to
connect entire experiences of humanity.
In any case, this one page of poetry is
more representative of B.H. Cohen than
three\ years of other affiliations with the
J.H.U. More than any newspaper story on
our political action with Goucher, or other
informative material that made such a
heavy impression on you and how you
perceive your relationship with reality.
The following comments were taken
from an interview with the author.
How do you feel about the role of art in
mankind?
"I'm not really convinced that there's
any reason per se for my writing in this

poetry is an art and not a craft, 1 still have
a long way to go. It's not a question of my
writing at some point in the future, better
than anyone else, but of writing
effectively, without mistakes, without
being as self-conscious of my gestu rings as
I now am,and of developing something, in
some way, significant."
The reason I chose this particular
author to interview is that he represents,
generally, my opinions of the role and
importance of art in our society. I feel
that art is the hope of mankind and that it
is something that is vastly neglected at
Hopkins, which should not be neglected,
ever. In the future, the feature page will
try to bring to its Hopkins audience a
sounder and broader view of the ways in
which men can express themselves more
naturally, and more about personal
relationships between people and the way
they experience their lives. This does not
mean that this will be the arts section of
the newspaper, but I hope it will be the
page where people express what is
important to them. The page will include
reviews of various books, movies, plays,
etc. There, will also be articles by various
people who have something they wish to
say that pertains to the format of the
page. Anyone who wishes is encouraged to
send in written or drawn material for
consideration in the page. Written material
should be from three to six double-spaced
typewritten pages. The address is:

Offense shines as Hopkins nabs first grid win
Two Harry Stringer
touchdown runs and a 231 total
offense performance by
quarterback Jack Thomas led the
Blue Jays to a 34-13 victory over
the hapless Ursinus Bears
Saturday in the first Hopkins win
of the 1973 football season.
Co-captain Thomas connected
on ten of his fifteen passes and
gained 94 yards on the ground,
including a ten yard third period
scamper into the endzone and a
47 yard display of broken field
elusiveness that set up the first
score of the afternoon.
"We improved in execution
tremendously," asserted Coach
Dennis Cox, attributing the

triumph to the team effort.
"The line is working much
better each week," he continued.
"The flip-flop idea is paying off,
for they are developing much
faster." The success of the
offesnive line is apparenrin the
productive rushing game and the
fact that Thomas had time to get
off accurate passes. This week
none of his throws were
purloined.
Defensively, the Bears were
hampered by the loss of All-MAC
middle guard Rick Abernethy,
who broke his ankle last week.
However, Ursinus was throttled
by the Blue Jay defenders all
afternoon and could not mount a
threat until the fourth quarter

after their fate had been sealed.
The Hopkins secondary was
particularly effective, blanketing
Bear receivers and picking off
ifive passes during the contest.
Freshman Brian Coulter's first
interception as a Blue Jay set up
the Thomas touchdown run
which concluded the Hopkins
scoring.
Brian's brother Jack opened
the scoring by pulling in an eight
yard Thomas pass in the waning
moments of the first quarter.
After Ursinus missed a field goal
attempt, Thomas hit Bill Nolan
for a 58 yard gain, with Stringer
tallying three plays later to give
the Blue Jays a 14-0 advantage.
After an exchange of

turnovers, freshman Mike
Rhodey cairn into his own with a
pair of strong runs and a five
yard score. "This awakening
should do a world of good for his
confidence," claimed Coach Cox
in regard to the converted
quarterback. Rhodey picked up
57 yards in six carries.
Thomas himself met with
success in the running
department. The F & M game
films showed that he had several
chances to pick up good yardage
on his roll outs, so the senior
signal caller purposefully
concentrated on the outside run
opportunities against Ursinus.
Thomas' gallops picked up
several key first downs for the

Good weather gives
Goucher Gallop go
In the most popular Goucher
Gallop of recent years, Kerry
Spaven's first place finish led
Willard to the dormitory title
while TEP prevailed over the
fraternity entries.
More than twice as many
runners than usual participated
this year, with fifty-eight
successfully completing the mile
and a half course. B1A President
Neil Hazard attributed the large
turnout to the brilliant weather
and the later noon start.
Spaven ran the course in 6:45
to beat out TEP's Doug
Southard for individual honors.
Mark Lewis, also of Willard,
placed third to give his house a

commanding advantage. Leo
Kusuda rounded out the Willard
win as the 20th man to complete
the course.
Griffin took second and
Sylvester placed third in the
dormitory competition.
TEP earned the lowest score of
all teams with Rick Jennings
finishing third and Ed Casey
copping the tenth spot for a team
total of 20. PI Kappa Alpha was
second with Sigma Nu and DU
rounding out the top fraternities.
The B1A bike race will be run
Saturday at 11 a.m. Entrants
must register with Chris Brescia
by Thursday at Box 69 or
243-9209.

Tennis
Registration for the Mixed
Doubles Tennis Tournament ends
Thursday. The tourney will be
held Octobei 19, 20, and 21 on
the Hopkins tennis courts. All
interested couples or singles
needing partners should sign up
at the Gym with Joyce

Water Polo
The Johns Hopkins Water Polo
team will host the University of
Delaware in the first home game
of the season. Friday night at
7:30 in the pool. Admission will
be free.
